Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen I am 
in Bangkok Thailand and usually I'd be roaming

the city eating delicious food but today I'm going 
to take you to see a lesser-known side of Bangkok

I have a special guest right here this is Dwight 
Turner some of you may recognize him he's got his

own brand new YouTube channel that you should 
check out he's also a blogger he's got bangkok

fatty calm and what's special about Dwight though 
is that he also organizes this great charity

project that does wonderful things with at-risk 
kids in Bangkok it's our project where we work

with kids help them to be a little more confident 
teach them some leadership skills give them in the

kitchen encourage the kids to eat better to cook 
better we support their families with some with

some nutritious products like vegetables and 
better supply so they can actually use to cook

Dwight took me to a house that serves as their 
community center and here every Saturday kids

come for an English class before they go and 
cook up a healthy lunch and even on a weekend

morning the room was just packed the program 
is run entirely by volunteers with people like

you I think the resident grandma who helps care 
for the kids and gives out hugs to anyone who

needs it Brian and exuberant and beloved English 
teacher from the US who usually teaches at her

local university mr. Howe a refugee himself who 
has become the community leader and he also helps

run the programs logistics while we waited for the 
kids to finish with their class Dwight takes me to

visit the home of two of the families that are 
supported by courageous kitchen and this was a

real eye-opener for me so the house that we were 
at is sort of the nicer community center where

everybody gets or gets together and do all these 
activities but this is the kind of place that the

families actually live in so in this little place 
there are two families this is sort of the normal

living situation back at the community center 
Dwight wraps up the class with prizes for the

hardest-working students of the year the kids were 
so happy and the room was just buzzing with energy

so after the kids are done with the English class 
upstairs they've broken up into stations and the

kid seems it just naturally gravitate towards 
one thing or another they find something to do

and they seem to just just go right it's a very 
you know they're self-directed almost just fine

so yeah so we they cook every weekend yeah so at 
the end of thing with these kids especially is

they're the older kids in the family right so they 
might have duties and responsibilities where they

actually have to like cook at home anyway we're 
just kind of giving them the direction like how to

use it correctly how not to cut yourself how to be 
safe I'm really surprised how confident they are

with just just taking things in large amounts and 
just doing it you know and it obviously they've

done it before so even though we're cooking with 
kids for kids this is the amount of chilies that

are going into our stir fried food tends to be 
quite simple here with lots of vegetables and

eggs but because today is the year-end party they 
have splurged on a few tilapia and the adults are

in charge of the grill so why you came to Thailand 
like in 2006 or something right or absolutely

anyone what brought you to Thailand to begin with 
I came here as a teacher originally at the end of

my year I took a reading and writing Thai reading 
and writing class and then I went home I came back

and I've been here ever since so when you came 
back that's when you got to know these people

yeah when I came back you know I was like I had 
already done the touristy stuff I had already

hit the party scene right pretty hard that first 
year so when I came back I was more like okay uh

what else is going on where can I give my time 
back until I met a friend who was a refugee yeah

things went from there in terms of just hanging 
out with him spending time with his family I

realize you know they need it hell I never thought 
it would turn into anything big you know it's just

like Oh buying food bringing it to a family making 
sure they organic Lee grew kind of organically

sounds nice it got a lot of frustration impatience 
with a lot of the religious organizations and

regular nonprofits that are here and like not 
really doing enough where do you see this going

do you have a plan for where where you want your 
dream or courageous kitchen I want to see it be

something that happens long term I want to see 
it happening not just this community I want to

see it happening in the Thai communities the goal 
is really like give them some confidence you know

they need a safe place to fail right this is safe 
place to failed and it's an easy place to learn

yeah when it's time to eat the older girls took 
charge of the buffet line they served everyone and

even control portion sizes to make sure big kids 
little kids all got the right amount of food the

kids get to eat first so while we waited I chatted 
with Dwight more about the challenges of working

with urban refugees I guess urban refugees is a 
kind of new term because people normally think

about refugees especially in Thailand we think 
about refugees in terms of the people that are

on the borders in refugee camps but modern-day 
times most people don't flee into these camps

they end up fleeing into cities so they have 
a language barrier they have they don't have

the ability to work and and then people you know 
there's instances where people take advantage Egon

it's such a hot topic like people some people like 
don't want anything to do with you when they know

you're working with refugees it's tough to kind of 
gauge what to tell people what not to tell people

how much is too much when are you overwhelming 
people people just want to know oh you help kids

oh that's cute like oh how can we help yeah I know 
can I Britain can I bring you some donuts Oh like

oh that doesn't really help me yeah but if you 
want to drop off some vegetables that would be

great so the biggest the biggest things are 
basically they're not eating enough which

complicates the fact that they have no access to 
health care which is complicated by the fact that

they can't work and support themselves so that 
I mean it's this whole mix of these main three

problems that kind of makes their their lives 
hell while they're living here mm-hmm so for you

personally why is it that this particular cost 
touches you the most eating a section universal

being like it's your happiest moment you know um 
it breaks my heart when you when people aren't

eating enough you know it's such an enjoyable 
thing it is something we take for granted right

and what's a party without music we're joined by

this one

all right so the party is well on its way a
